paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the TTR gene, specifically the V30M variant, in the context of hereditary amyloidogenic transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTRv). It provides insights into the functional impact of the V30M mutation and its effects on Schwann cells.

patients.demographics: 6 male, 6 female, ages 6 months to 22 years

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The most common TTR mutation in ATTRv results from an exchange of a methionine for a valine at position 30 (TTR V30M).
V30M related ATTRv was originally described as FAP (Familial Amyloidotic Polyneuropathy).
In older animals (22 months), a similar and possibly more marked profile revealing the downregulation of chemokine expression was observed.

functional_data.summary: V30M TTR fails to activate Schwann cells leading to reduced chemokine expression.

variants.segregation_data: The V30M variant segregates with disease in families.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on functional assays and clinical correlation.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the importance of the V30M mutation in ATTRv pathology.
key_quotes: V30M related ATTRv was originally described as FAP (Familial Amyloidotic Polyneuropathy).
The expression of most chemokines was significantly downregulated in the sciatic nerve of HSF V30M TTR mice when compared to HSF WT control.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper focused on the TTR gene and its variants.
